text: Hey <!channel> I spent some time last night doing some research on  the new iOS sizes and there're a couple of interesting things that may affect our workflow.

The 6+ will need @3x assets and the 6 @2x. Here's the thing: While the assets we give to  dev are @2x and @3x  the phone will upscale the @2x to 2.46x and @3x to 3.3. That means things like a crisp 1pt line may not be as easy to do as before.
This may be a question for the <#C028L147V> channel, but does this mean that apps will now be that much heavier now due to having a third file to pull from for each of these images @3x?
I can answer that and it's a big YES.
so if we are supporting all sizes, we will have to prepare 4 files?
I think it's 3: 1x, 2x, 3x
1x, 2x (iphone 4/5), 2x (6) and 3x (6+)
hm ok so the 2x gets upsize d by the device itself
ok
so the iphone 6 display is slightly lower res?
I guess exporting in 2.46 then compressing to 2 doesn't help?
(so that the phone would get the exported version when it uncompresses it?)
<@U026PT0D7>: That would probably be a half pixel double-whammy of terror.
ah, yeah
Devs and designers on twitter have been talking about using SVG instead of rasters but that's outside my understanding in terms of implementation.
it seems strange that apple would go for the best display possible then upsample everything anyway
Yes, that's crazy. Unless they figured out a way to do it well.
if apple provided their upsampling algorithm then presumably we could downsample a 2.46x image to 2x
but then it would look good only on 6/6+, and bad on all other phones...
I think we're slowly moving towards more scalable methods of designing stuff. I.E, vector. The web has been doing that for years I think iOS and Android will get there soon.
that would be nice :)
